awd_titl_txt: Planetesimal formation, giant planet migration, and stellar accretion in our solar system and beyond
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).  Graham Edwards is awarded an NSF Astronomy and Astrophysics Postdoctoral Fellowship to conduct a program of research and education at Dartmouth College.  Edwards will perform a computational statistical study of meteorite chemical composition to elucidate planetary formation processes in the early Solar System.  Results from this study will refine our understanding of the history of the Solar System and inform models of extrasolar systems.   For the education component of this project, Edwards will develop a museum outreach program to explore how scientists use meteorites to study Solar System history and planet formation.

This project will extract meteorite chemical compositions from the largest centralized collection of publicly available meteorite data to study (1) relationships between meteorites and their constituent components, (2) timescales of giant planet migration, and (3) the role of the protoplanetary disk in shaping the solar composition.  This statistical study will test whether bulk chemical clustering improves upon standard methods of grouping meteorites into families and whether constituent chondrites or chondrite matrices formed from a shared reservoir of material.  The project will also test whether the deficit of refractory elements in the solar photosphere is due to their preferential incorporation in protoplanetary bodies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Award 2102591 funded the postdoctoral fellowship of PI Dr. Graham H. Edwards. Under this award, Edwards used computational techniques to answer fundamental questions about the earliest stages of solar system history. Concomitant with this research, Edwards ran a museum-based public education program at a local science museum (Montshire Museum of Science). The major Scientific Outcomes and Broader Impacts of this award are outlined below:


Scientific Outcomes
Edwards and colleagues compiled a database of thermochronologic data from chondrite meteorites. (Thermochronology uses the radioactive decay of certain heat-sensitive elements to measure and estimate when mineral systems heated or cooled) They developed a software that uses a Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm to estimate the timescales of energetic asteroid bombardment in the early solar system from meteorite thermochronology (ImpactChron.jl). Using this new software with the new database, Edwards and colleagues provided an answer to a longstanding debate in planetary science and astronomy: when did the solar system's giant planets migrate from the orbits they originally formed in to their current orbital configuration. This new estimate of giant planet migration falls early in solar system history and associates this migration with the transition between a gaseous protoplanetary disk and mature planetary system. Edwards and colleagues published these findings in Nature Astronomy (Edwards+ 2024, doi:10.1038/s41550-024-02340-6).

Based on the study's broad appeal and timeliness, Nature Astronomy editors selected this article to be featured in an associated "Research Briefing", a peer-reviewed accessible summary published alongside the larger, more technical article to improve its broad reach to the scientific and popular public: "Giant planets migrated shortly after the Solar System’s protoplanetary disk dispersed" (Edwards 2024, doi:10.1038/s41550-024-02341-5)

Through this work, Edwards established himself as an expert in this field. He was interviewed for popular science publications in Science Magazine and Sky & Telescope.

Another major scientific goal of this fellowship was to investigate the chemical composition of the Sun compared to other Sun-like "solar twin" stars. Prior studies have shown that the Sun has a slight but measurable deficit in so-called "refractory" elements (elements that tend to concentrate in solids rather than gases and are found more abundantly in planets). The origins of this difference may be related to planet formation, but still remains unclear. Edwards mentored a student who examined this question from a stellar population perspective (Rampalli+ 2024, ApJ, doi:10.3847/1538-4357/ad303e). To explore this from a more solar system-oriented perspective, Edwards developed a new software (SolarChem.jl) that uses statistical methods to both accurately and precisely estimate model chemical compositions of different meteorite families. At the time of writing, this software is ready to begin testing hypotheses related to early planetesimal populations and the Sun's chemical compostion using data from the Astromaterials Data System.

In addition to these major scientific outcomes over the tenure of this award, Edwards completed two publications from his graduate studies: "Terrestrial evidence for ocean forcing of Heinrich events and subglacial hydrologic connectivity of the Laurentide Ice Sheet" (Edwards+ 2022, Science Advances, 10.1126/sciadv.abp9329) and "Uranium-series isotopes as tracers of physical and chemical weathering in glacial sediments from Taylor Valley, Antarctica" (Edwards+ 2025, Chemical Geology, doi:10.1016/j.chemgeo.2024.122463). 

Broader Impacts
Edwards developed an active outreach program with the Montshire Museum of Science, a family-oriented science museum in Norwich, VT. Edwards improved upon an existing meteorite-identification activity to develop new materials that remain in use after his departure. He also developed a scientific "tour" of the inner solar system leveraging the museum's "Planet Trail" that used meteorite samples to supplement narrative-style science communication. In addition to this regular programming at the Museum, Edwards was featured as a speaker for Astronomy Day and eclipse events within and beyond the Museum. 

Edwards developed a broad mentorship network among graduate and undergraduate students in the Departments of Earth Science and Physics & Astronomy at the host institution, Dartmouth College. For instance, Edwards mentored PhD candidate R. Rampalli in the work Rampalli+ 2024 (ApJ, doi:10.3847/1538-4357/ad303e) and mentored undergraduate student co-author C.W. Stewart of Edwards+ 2024 (Nature Astronomy, doi:10.1038/s41550-024-02340-6). Edwards also taught introductory classes in the Department of Physics & Astronomy.
